In this thread, I'd like to step away from the testimony wars, doctrinal disputes, and creation myths, and stand on neutral territory in order to examine some aspects of the social and political utility of religion. 
 
 From an external perspective - let's say that of an anthropologist or even my favorite hypothetical figure, the "impartial observer" - the functions of religion in society look very different from the view taken on interior lines by the faithful. In other words, a clinical inquiry reveals "socio-political facts" about a religion that might be either invisible or not important to its clients. After a brief survey of some of these "facts", some with positive effects and others having a negative impact, I want to draw attention to a relationship between a certain religious outlook and an economic system.
 
 If we subject religious enthusiasm to a dispassionate scrutiny, we must concede straight away that a number of pluses might be detected in a society which has been penetrated by religious ideas/ideals. For example: religion tends to promote social cohesion and makes a significant contribution to the creation of a cultural identity; religion tends to bind society together under the aegis of an "absolute" moral law; the quality of aesthetic achievements in art, literature, and music is much influenced by religious sentiments, etc., etc. (More could be added, but the general idea has been outlined). 
 
 On the minus side, religion acts as a conservative brake in society and tends to support or even to sanctify the authority of the powers that be.  Hitler believed in telling the "big lie," and there are some today who have been duped into continuing to propagate some of his lies. Specifically, I'm talking about Internet atheist types who--incredibly--assert that Adolf Hitler was a Christian. This notion can easily be dispelled by performing a very meager amount of research--which is exactly what I've done. 
 I recently read the book Hitler's Cross, by Erwin W. Lutzer. The information contained in that book puts Hitler's "Christianity" in a very revealing light. I haven't double-checked Lutzer's sources, though the book seems quite trustworthy to me. But just to assure the reliability of my case I'll also quote from William Shirer's classic, The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich, which the New York Times called "one of the most important works of history of our time" and "a splendid work of scholarship, objective in method, sound in judgment, inescapable in its conclusions." 
 
 First of all, in order to determine whether Hitler was a Christian, we need to define "Christian." If by Christian we mean someone who believes the words of Jesus and tries to follow them, then Hitler was absolutely, unquestionably not a Christian. But if by "Christian" we mean "a person who claimed to be a Christian but whose real goal was to do away with Christianity and instead have himself revered as the most exalted being ever to walk the earth," then, well, Hitler was a Christian. But to define such a person as a Christian would be absurd. We might as well say that because Hitler wanted to conquer and devour Poland and France that he was a Pole or a Frenchman. 
 
 Now it's true that in his youth Hitler must have had, at least for a time, some kind of Christian belief, since he tells us that as a boy he had a passing interest in becoming a clergyman. But that ended. At some time in his life Hitler apparently turned completely against Christianity. 
 Yes, he did make public claims to Christianity even while he was in power and persecuting Christians. But those public professions were simply lies. He made them in order to win the support of the German people, but in reality he wanted to do away with Christianity as it had hitherto been known and pervert it into a mere facade for Nazism and worship of himself as the ultimate leader.  "[Making peace with the church] won't stop me from stamping out Christianity in Germany, root and branch. One is either a Christian or a German. You can't be both." (J. S. Conway, The Nazi Persecution of the Churches, quoted in Lutzer, pp. 113-114.)

 In a determinedly contrived effort to pull the thread back on track, let me return to the notion aired many posts ago that one of religion's most (literally) mundane utilities lies in the legitimation of a society's ruling group. The pagan Norse kings of the European Dark Ages were credited with elaborately detailed genealogies tracing their ancestry back, inevitably, to Wotan; after their conversion to christianity, these same genealogies were simply extended, with breathtaking pragmatism, back to Noah, Lamech and beyond. (Asser's genealogy of Alfred the Great is an excellent example.)
 
 To modern eyes these family trees are so obviously fictitious that we can't understand why anyone at the time took them seriously; but that is to miss their point. The people who drew them up had no historical sense in the way we understand it; for a people with a purely oral record of their past, objective fact was a side issue. The function of the genealogy was to explain and legitimise the status quo.

 There are several on this forum who insist, and will keep insisting, that there can be no morality without a higher being to issue it. This is clearly nonsense: a moral code is as functionally adaptive to a society as its language, and our brains have evolved to acquire both, in predictable developmental sequences, during our early childhood. The difference with morality is that we are faced with realistic choices in applying it; and it is the nature of moral codes that approved behaviours are those that operate to the good of the society, even if they are to the detriment of the individual.
 
 In those circumstances it is tempting to speculate that cultures which ascribed their moral teachings to an all-powerful higher authority are likely to have been more successful than those that did not. Even those of us without religious belief tend to regard abstractions such as 'justice' and 'rights' as if they were absolute goods existing on some higher plane, not mere manifestations of the survival value inherent in reciprocal altruism.

 Yes, it's a very close analogy. Chomsky's work (and Pinker's) strongly suggests that the brain's 'wiring' is pre-adapted for the acquisition of language. Kohler has made a similar suggestion re the acquisition of moral rules. If there is a similar pre-disposition to seek and find cause-and-effect relationships, then a drive to generate causes for otherwise inexplicable phenomena might well lead to a belief in the existence of invisible causal agents; and this could underlie the evolution of what you call religious sensibility.
 
 Before anyone else points them out, I'm fully aware of the ifs and mights and coulds in that statement, and will reiterate that this is no more than a plausible conjecture. Evidence for it is hard to come by, though Lewis Wolpert has written interestingly about evidence arising from certain kinds of mental illness.
 
 On edit. The above might lead people to assume that by this argument religion is a 'mere' spin-off of some other brain function. Even it arose that way, as the topic of this thread attests it did not stay that way. Evolutionary biologists are familiar with the concept of 'pre-adaptation': a structure or process or behaviour that evolved to fit one function provides the raw material, by a different selective pressure, to be adapted to a different one. Even if a belief in the numinous was a side effect in the first instance, many posts above have shown how functional it was to prove in social and cultural evolution.
